>  I realized that I never asked Julian specifically if they focus on
>  TW=
EANN approaches to NE, but judging by the work that he, personally,
>  has =
done, it would appear so.  Regardless, I'll soon find out.
>  

Many of the=
 more important people there seem to have a penchant for
small, fully conne=
cted, continuous networks, such as CTRNNs and
spiking models. I myself thin=
k that having a network fully connected
can be disastrous to evolvability, =
as a change in any connection will
affect every neuron in the network. Epis=
tasis is the word. What is
interesting about CTRNNs and similar nets is tha=
t every neuron has
state and decay properties, which can be used for some i=
nteresting
integration of information over time. The tend to be quite
compu=
tationally expensive, though, and I go with much simpler neuron
models for =
my current experiments with very large networks.

Having said that, several=
 of the people there have done forays into
artificial embryogeny, and Gruau=
 (of Cellular Encoding fame) was there
for a while. And you are very much f=
ree to do whatever you want in the
EASy programme - they probably wouldn't =
object too much if you handed
in an oil painting or something you built out=
 of matchsticks and
crumbled bread instead of an essay... (Well, they might=
 not be that
liberal, but almost.)

>  Examining the Universities in Britis=
h Columbia (EA headquarters), I
>  see a lot of AI possibilities but nothin=
g that mentions anything close
>  to NE.  Shame.

J=F6rg Denzinger works wi=
th EA on evolutionary approaches (unintended
acronym pun there) to finding =
"sweet spots" in games amongst other
things - interesting research. I don't=
 know how much he is into neural
networks, though. The work I've seen by hi=
m is on evolving action
sequences.

http://pages.cpsc.ucalgary.ca/~denzinge=
/

I just read a dissertation by a guy called Pieter Spronck
(http://www.cs=
.unimaas.nl/p.spronck/) from Maastricht on evolutionary
game ai. Interestin=
g, but again no neural nets. It seems people
believe less in neural nets th=
an in evolution for game AI purposes.
